forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: A military or security elite topples an incumbent in a fragile African state (e.g., Chad, Guinea-Bissau, DRC) and consolidates control, or a sitting leader in Latin America or Africa executes a self-coup (e.g., dissolving legislature/annulling results) and faces no significant resistance, thereby establishing control over state and military before July 1.
forecast.rationale: Base rate: The recent African coup wave (Mali 2020 & 2021, Chad 2021, Guinea 2021, Sudan 2021, Burkina Faso twice in 2022, Niger 2023, Gabon 2023) implies roughly 1.5–2 successful coups/year during 2020–2023. On a 66-day window (~0.18 of a year), a naive Poisson with 2/year gives ~28% for ≥1 coup. However, 2024 saw no successful coups, suggesting the wave may have cooled and several highest-risk states are already under military rule, shrinking the near-term target set. Latin America’s modern base rate for successful coups is very low; recent events (Peru 2022 self-coup attempt, Brazil 2023 unrest, Bolivia 2024 attempt) failed, and there are no imminent high-risk electoral triggers before July 1, 2025. Signals: Africa still shows underlying fragility. There was a possible coup attempt in Chad in Jan 2025 and a thwarted attempt in DRC in May 2024—evidence of persistent elite-military tensions that could crystallize quickly. Sahel juntas’ consolidation may lower short-run risk of additional takeovers within those regimes, but places like Chad, Guinea-Bissau, or DRC remain watchlist candidates. Latin America: My assistant notes no attempts reported so far in 2025, Venezuela remains tense but Maduro already controls the security apparatus, and Bolsonaro’s legal defense in Brazil is backward-looking. Macro headwinds (e.g., weaker growth) rarely translate into coups within a two-month horizon absent a political trigger. Why not higher: Limited time window; the 2024 lull; many prime candidates already under juntas; no clear imminent Latin American trigger. Why not lower: The African base rate remains elevated relative to the 2000s–2010s; recent failed attempts show readiness and intent; coups can be fast-moving with little public forewarning. What would move me up: Credible reports of elite splits or mutinies in a fragile African state (especially Chad/Guinea-Bissau/DRC), mass protests paired with military neutrality/defection, or signs of a self-coup in a country facing an immediate institutional clash. What would move me down: Weeks of quiet across known hotspots, successful security purges/reshuffles that eliminate rivals, or international mediation that visibly lowers tensions. Assistant’s inputs incorporated: No 2025 Latin American attempts to date; Venezuela and Brazil developments appear legal/political rather than imminent forceful moves; macro downgrades don’t change short-term coup odds meaningfully.

This question resolves as **Yes** if there is a successful coup d’état in any country on the African continent or Latin America before July 1, 2025, according to credible media reports. If this does not occur, this question resolves as **No**.

Latin America is defined as any country in North America or South America whose primary language is Spanish, Portuguese or French.

A coup d’état (often shortened to "coup") is [defined](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coup_d'%C3%A9tat) as an event in which a state's military or other components of its power structure overthrow the existing political authority. 

A "successful" coup is defined as a coup in which the group or person attempting to seize power establishes control over both the government and military, and will be considered to have succeeded once any significant resistance to their authority has ceased. 

A self-coup, [defined](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-coup) as a political leader, having come to power through legal means, remaining in power through illegal means, will count. This includes scenarios in which an incumbent leader refuses to relinquish power after an election.

External support for a coup, such as is described [here](https://africacenter.org/spotlight/africas-coups-and-the-role-of-external-actors/), will count as long as the mercenaries or other external actors are acting in support of a perpetrator from within the state.

Civil wars, mutinies, rebellions or popular uprisings will not count, nor will changes to a country's constitution that restrict a country's democratic norms.
